moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 c6: The Blackburne Gambit.  Black gives up a pawn to try to get faster development.
moves.3. dxc6 Nxc6 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 Bf5 6. d3: This might be unnecessary, as it blocks in the light-square Bishop.
moves.6... h6 7. Be2 e6 8. O-O Be7 9. Re1 O-O: Black has slightly better Bishops and a tiny lead in development, but is still down a pawn.
moves.10. Nh4: Very anti-positional to put the Knight on the edge of the board.
moves.10... Bh7 11. Bd2 a6 12. a3 Rc8: Black tries to use the semi-open file.
moves.13. Bf3 Nd5: Now the h4 Knight is attacked twice.
moves.14. Nxd5 exd5 15. g3 Bxh4 16. gxh4 Qxh4: Now material is even, although White can retain the pawn with Bxd5.  The bigger problem for White is that the King is now exposed.
moves.17. Bg4 Rcd8 18. Bf4 Qf6: Double attack on the Bf4 and b2.
moves.19. Bg3 Rfe8 20. c3 Rxe1+: Rxe1 removes the defender of d3.
moves.21. Qxe1 Bxd3 22. f4: White's King is already exposed.  f4 just makes increases the vulnerability.
moves.22... Qg6 23. h3 h5 24. f5: If the Bishop on g5 moves away, the pawn will continue to h4 and win the pinned Bg3.
moves.24... Bxf5: But this way, White is still able to snag another pawn.
moves.25. Bxf5 Qxf5 26. Qd2 Qxh3: Yet another pawn--and now the King is completely exposed.  I think White just may have missed this hanging pawn.
moves.27. Qg2 Qxg2+ 28. Kxg2: Black is happy to trade Queens with a three-pawn edge.  All three of Black's Kingside pawns are unopposed.
moves.28... d4 29. cxd4 Rxd4: Black trades off the isolated pawn just to make the endgame win simpler.
moves.30. b4 f6 31. Bc7 Kf7 32. Bb6 Rg4+ 33. K: The e4 N is covering the d7 square, so that Black's R can't create problems.
This forces a trade of the Bishop and Knight, again simplifying the endgame win.
moves.40. Ke2 Nxc5 41. bxc5 Rxc5: But now, White's R can penetrate.  It won't matter because of the material deficit.
moves.42. Rd7+ Kg6 43. Rxb7 Rc4 44. a5 Rc5: White cannot protect a5 and so will lose another pawn.
moves.45. Rb6 Rxa5 46. Kd3 h4 47. Ke2 g4 48. K: White's King cannot do much to stop the pawns.
moves.48... Ra3 49. Kg2 Kg5 50. Rc6 Ra2+ 51. K: Once the Rook starts to help, the White King is confined to the edge of the board.
moves.51... h3 52. Rc5+ f5 53. Kf1 g3 54. Rd5: Now Black can force a pawn through to promotion.
moves.57. Kxh3 Ra3+: Qh1+ is a way to win the Rook, but this checkmate is forced, and faster too.
moves.58. Rd3 Rxd3#: Finis.  White's problems started with Na4.  Before that the position was quite solid.  With a pawn advantage, the goal should be just to play solid and try to get to a favorable endgame.  Perhaps White just tried to do too much.
